body:
rclone v1.46.0-067-g1a019292-fix-3032-suffix-keep-extension-beta
- os/arch: windows/amd64
- go version: go1.11

Zipping -vv from both a standard run and the first part of a --fast-list (stopped as soon as it starts uploading files). Will email shortly.

That is strange... The main difference between the non fast list and the fast list is that we use batch operations to list more directories at once.

Can you try playing with this constant to see if it makes a difference?  Try making it smaller

https://github.com/ncw/rclone/blob/f5795db6d2fb6b321f0568c418ea86698fa11490/backend/drive/drive.go#L1489

@B4dM4n any ideas?

Ya, I see that non-fast is requesting each folder by itself. The fast-list requests are asking for multiple at a time (Up to a certain number of characters?) and are just getting a blank response back. See line 9277 on the fastlist log for the first one. 9245 above it was successful.

```
c
{"files":[]}
0
```

The folders all appear to be listed, just the item responses are being returned blank.

I unfortunately am not setup to build. I'll test a modified version if you have it though.

Yes that looks like the problem. This query

```
2019/04/15 08:37:47 DEBUG : GET /drive/v3/files?alt=json&corpora=teamDrive&fields=files%28id%2Cname%2Csize%2Cmd5Checksum%2Ctrashed%2CmodifiedTime%2CcreatedTime%2CmimeType%2Cparents%2CwebViewLink%29%2CnextPageToken&includeTeamDriveItems=true&pageSize=1000&prettyPrint=false&q=trashed%3Dfalse+and+%28%XXX%27+in+parents+or+%27XXX%27+in+parents+or+%27XXX%27+in+parents+or+...+in+parents%29&supportsTeamDrives=true&teamDriveId=XXX HTTP/1.1
```

Returned

```
{"files":[]}
```

Which is surely wrong.

So this **is** a bug in google drive I'd say.

However, can we work around it...?

Here is an rclone with `--drive-fast-list-grouping` - this defaults to 50 - can you try experimenting with it to see if you can it to work at some value?  I'd try 25,10,5,2,1

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.47.0-006-gad7078c3-fix-3114-teamdrive-listr-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

You could also try `rclone size` just to count the files.  This will use `--fast-list` by default now - if you don't want it to, use `--disable ListR`

Ran with Non, Fast, 25, 10, 5 and 1.
1 behaves exactly like Non Fast-List. The rest are all missing files (the number varies slightly)

```
c:\rclone\test>rclone size Drive1_19k:Test --disable ListR
Total objects: 109345
Total size: 3.851 GBytes (4135425516 Bytes)

c:\rclone\test>rclone size Drive1_19k:Test
Total objects: 945
Total size: 26.572 MBytes (27863240 Bytes)

c:\rclone\test>rclone size Drive1_19k:Test --drive-fast-list-grouping 25
Total objects: 2835
Total size: 77.405 MBytes (81165497 Bytes)

c:\rclone\test>rclone size Drive1_19k:Test --drive-fast-list-grouping 10
Total objects: 3980
Total size: 109.123 MBytes (114423575 Bytes)

c:\rclone\test>rclone size Drive1_19k:Test --drive-fast-list-grouping 5
Total objects: 3558
Total size: 99.308 MBytes (104131739 Bytes)

c:\rclone\test>rclone size Drive1_19k:Test --drive-fast-list-grouping 1
Total objects: 109345
Total size: 3.851 GBytes (4135425516 Bytes)
```


Looking closer into the responses

Unfortunately, it appears that the response to an actual empty folder is the exact same as the blank response we're getting from the batch requests

Eg, in the nonfastlist.log I sent previously

Rclone initially learns about it's existence in the response at 9672.
line 11296 is the request for the items inside the blank folder
Response comes back at 11599


With that in mind I see a few options 

1. Assume a blank response to a --fast-list request is invalid and queue up those items as individual requests as well.

Pros:
Should always find the files
Transparent to the user
Cons:
Potentially more API calls then just running without --fast-list (At least off the bat, until google drive catches up)

2. Warn/Error when blank responses are received Eg. "RClone received a blank response from a Google Drive request, This can sometimes indicate that files have not yet been indexed on the remote side. Consider running without --fast-list"

Pros:
Won't waste API calls
Notifies the user of a potential issue

Cons:
There are legitimate blank folder situations that will trigger the warning.
Situations where it returns some files but not all of them would not be detectable.
Might not be visible if the user is running a headless setup.

3. Disable --fast-list on team drives until google can fix their end.

Pros:
Should always work
Cons:
Slower and more API calls
Probably a bit excessive.

Option 1 sounds feasible...

Option 2 sounds workable too, since all the directories you were querying would have to be empty to produce a false positive.

3. Also a good plan... I couldn't find an existing issue about this though - can you? https://issuetracker.google.com/
This is the best I could come up with: https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/75001471

Ya, that looks to be the same symptoms. That one only has a single item so it populates rather quickly, I'm surprised it was even detectable.
Having 100k+ like I've got is amplifying it considerably.

> Option 2 sounds workable too, since all the directories you were querying would have to be empty to produce a false positive.

I'd be more concerned about false negatives in that situation. I've only seen examples of returning all data and returning no data, I'm guessing it's also possible to return only some of the data. Finding an example of this might be tricky.

> This is the best I could come up with: https://issuetracker.google.com/issues/75001471

His work-around of adding a 3 second delay before the query for a single file does seem to match my approximate 1500-2000 files per hour measurement as well. If the "bug" on google's end truly is a throttle or account limitation then there may not ever be a fix.

Just got the email for changes to Drive API, including some adjustments to team drives. 

https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/application-development/upcoming-changes-to-the-google-drive-api-and-google-picker-api

https://developers.google.com/drive/api/v3/reference/files/list

issue.title: Google Drive LSD Inconsistent when using a Service Account

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?
Getting a directory listing using lsd from a google drive team drive responds with an incomplete listing, after some retries, the entire listing comes through.

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)
rclone v1.46.0-112-g1c301f9f-beta
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.12.1

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)
Distributor ID:	Debian
Description:	Debian GNU/Linux 9.5 (stretch)
Release:	9.5
Codename:	stretch

####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)
Google Drive

#### The command you were trying to run (eg `rclone copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
rclone - -config="/media/sda1/xxxxx/.config/rclone/backups-serviceaccounts.rclone.conf" --drive-service-account-file="/media/sda1/xxxxx/.config/rclone/rclone-client-id-xxxxx-xxxxx.json" --drive-impersonate=xxxxx@xxxxxxxx.com --low-level-retries=1 --retries=1 lsd Backups2:

declare -x RCLONE_DRIVE_CHUNK_SIZE="512M"
declare -x RCLONE_FAST_LIST="true"
declare -x RCLONE_LOG_LEVEL="DEBUG"
declare -x RCLONE_PROGRESS="true"
declare -x RCLONE_STATS=".1s"
declare -x RCLONE_STATS_FILE_NAME_LENGTH="0"
declare -x RCLONE_STATS_UNIT="bits"
declare -x RCLONE_TPSLIMIT="10"

issue.title: Rclone size reports incorrect size if --fast-list is used ( default behaviour )

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--

Welcome :-) We understand you are having a problem with rclone; we want to help you with that!

If you've just got a question or aren't sure if you've found a bug then please use the rclone forum:

    https://forum.rclone.org/

instead of filing an issue for a quick response.

If you think you might have found a bug, please can you try to replicate it with the latest beta?

    https://beta.rclone.org/
    
If you can still replicate it with the latest beta, then please fill in the info below which makes our lives much easier.  A log with -vv will make our day :-)

Thank you

The Rclone Developers

-->

#### What is the problem you are having with rclone?

```rclone size remote:``` reports incorrect size for non team drive remotes if --fast-list is used . If i use ```rclone size remote: --disable ListR``` , i am getting accurate results

#### What is your rclone version (output from `rclone version`)

rclone v1.52.0

#### Which OS you are using and how many bits (eg Windows 7, 64 bit)

- os/arch: windows/386
- go version: go1.14.3

####  Which cloud storage system are you using? (eg Google Drive)

Google Drive

#### A log from the command with the `-vv` flag (eg output from `rclone -vv copy /tmp remote:tmp`)
**Actual size - 2.853 gb**
**Test with rclone size remote:**
```
PS C:\rclone> rclone size test: -vv
2020/05/28 22:57:48 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.52.0" starting with parameters ["C:\\rclone\\rclone.exe" "size" "test:" "-vv"]
2020/05/28 22:57:48 DEBUG : Using config file from "C:\\Users\\Sanjeev\\.config\\rclone\\rclone.conf"
Total objects: 63
Total size: 292.184 MBytes (306377599 Bytes)
2020/05/28 22:57:52 DEBUG : 18 go routines active
PS C:\rclone> rclone size test: -vv
2020/05/28 22:58:01 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.52.0" starting with parameters ["C:\\rclone\\rclone.exe" "size" "test:" "-vv"]
2020/05/28 22:58:01 DEBUG : Using config file from "C:\\Users\\Sanjeev\\.config\\rclone\\rclone.conf"
Total objects: 74
Total size: 334.623 MBytes (350877842 Bytes)
2020/05/28 22:58:03 DEBUG : 18 go routines active
```
As you can see its incorrect and even reports inconsistent size randomly everytime

**Test with rclone size remote: --disable ListR**
```
PS C:\rclone> rclone size test: --disable ListR -vv
2020/05/28 23:05:18 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.52.0" starting with parameters ["C:\\rclone\\rclone.exe" "size" "test:" "--disable" "ListR" "-vv"]
2020/05/28 23:05:18 DEBUG : Using config file from "C:\\Users\\Sanjeev\\.config\\rclone\\rclone.conf"
2020/05/28 23:05:18 DEBUG : Reset feature "ListR"
Total objects: 354
Total size: 2.853 GBytes (3063873067 Bytes)
2020/05/28 23:05:31 DEBUG : 18 go routines active
PS C:\rclone> rclone size test: --disable ListR -vv
2020/05/28 23:05:38 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.52.0" starting with parameters ["C:\\rclone\\rclone.exe" "size" "test:" "--disable" "ListR" "-vv"]
2020/05/28 23:05:38 DEBUG : Using config file from "C:\\Users\\Sanjeev\\.config\\rclone\\rclone.conf"
2020/05/28 23:05:38 DEBUG : Reset feature "ListR"
Total objects: 354
Total size: 2.853 GBytes (3063873067 Bytes)
2020/05/28 23:05:40 DEBUG : 18 go routines active
```
As you can see --disabling fast list gives correct results
Although please note that fast list doesnt seem bugged for team drive remotes and personal drives , so anyone who wanna reproduce this , dont test it on a team drive or personal drive remote
 It could be someone else's Gdrive folder which is public or shared with you
For someone who wanna quickly test it , i am dropping my rclone config file , just replace your token
```
[test]
type = drive
scope = drive
root_folder_id = 1vbyJ26ojnw5NvEpL2mrRkl5N--zqc1yZ
token = {"access_token":#####"}
```
( the google folder is public so anyone can test it themselves  its the very same 2.853 gb sized folder used in my test remote  )

**NOTE** - _The issue is not with rclone size but rather with --fast-list flag . Even if i do a rclone copy with --fast-list flag enabled for the above remote , it skips files just like it does while rclone size .I have chosen rclone size to show bugged --fast-list because its quicker than reproducing with rclone copy
